To determine the number of ways to assign each position as either D (with 6 H and 6 A) or N (with 12 H and 12 A), we can break down the problem into steps:

1. Choose which 12 positions out of 36 will be D. This is given by the binomial coefficient \( \binom{36}{12} \).
2. Assign 6 H and 6 A to these 12 D positions. This is given by another binomial coefficient \( \binom{12}{6} \).
3. Assign 12 H and 12 A to the remaining 24 N positions. This is given by another binomial coefficient \( \binom{24}{12} \).

Multiplying these together gives us the total number of ways:

\[
\boxed{\dbinom{36}{12} \dbinom{12}{6} \dbinom{24}{12}}
\]
